translated: The Collection of Long Discourses .
The Sutta on Kapila (the Discourse on the Practice of Dhamma)
The practice of Dhamma, the spiritual life,
This is said to be the highest good.

analyzed: pabbajitaḥ pi ce hoti  agārāḥ anagāriya
translated: Even if one goes forth,🔽from home to the homeless life,
If one is of a quarrelsome nature,
delighting in contention,
One’s life is worse,
one just increases one’s own dust.
A monk who delights in contention,
enveloped by the state of delusion,
Does not know even what is said,
the Dhamma taught by the Buddha.
For one who cultivates contention,
preceded by ignorance,
One does not know the defilement,
the path leading to hell.
Having fallen into the lower realms,
womb to womb, darkness to darkness;
Such a monk,
after death, goes to suffering.
Like a cesspool,
filled to the brim with rain water;
And if one were like this,
one’s inner courtyard is difficult to purify.
Whatever of this kind you know,
monks, that is based on the household life;
With bad desires, bad intentions,
bad conduct and resort.
All of you, being united,
and then you can get rid of him.
Get rid of the chaff,
and throw out the straw.
Then drive out the non-monks,
the conceited ones,
the wicked ones,

analyzed: pāpa ācāra gocare  suddhā suddhehi savāsa
translated: who live in bad ways.🔽The pure ones should live together with the pure ones,
mindful and clearly knowing,
then, united and alert,
you will make an end to suffering.”
The Discourse on Dhamma Conduct is the sixth.
